required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Pre-workout Supplement Versus Caffeine on Energy Expenditure.
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of a Multi-ingredient Pre-workout Supplement Versus Caffeine on Energy Expenditure and Feelings of Fatigue During Low-intensity Treadmill Exercise in College-aged Males.

brief_summary.textblock: The primary purpose of this study was to examine the acute effects of a multi-ingredient pre-workout supplement versus an ergogenic dose of caffeine (6 mg/kg) on energy expenditure during low-intensity exercise. The effects of these substances on substrate utilization, gas exchange, and psychological factors were also investigated. Twelve males (mean ± SD: age = 22.8 ± 2.4 years) completed three bouts of 60-min of treadmill exercise at 4.8-6.4 km/hr on separate days after consuming a pre-workout supplement, 6 mg/kg of caffeine, or placebo in a randomized fashion. The pre-workout and caffeine supplements resulted in significantly greater energy expenditure (p < 0.001, p = 0.006, respectively), VO2 (p < 0.001, p = 0.007, respectively), VCO2 (p = 0.006, p = 0.049, respectively), and VE (p < 0.001, p = 0.007, respectively), but not rates of fat or carbohydrate oxidation or respiratory exchange ratio compared to placebo (collapsed across condition). In addition, the pre-workout supplement increased feelings of alertness (p = 0.015) and focus (p = 0.005) 30-minutes post-ingestion and decreased feelings of fatigue (p = 0.014) during exercise compared to placebo (collapsed across condition). Thus, the pre-workout supplement increased energy expenditure and measures of gas exchange to the same extent as 6 mg/kg of caffeine with concomitant increased feelings of alertness and focus and decreased feelings of fatigue.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Measured continuously during 60 minutes of exercise for all three supplement conditions
primary_outcome.description: Measurement of caloric expenditure via gas exchange

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured continuously during 60 minutes of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of rate of oxygen consumption using a metabolic cart

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured continuously during 60 minutes of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of rate of carbon dioxide production using a metabolic cart

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured continuously during 60 minutes of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Measurement of ventilation rate using a metabolic cart

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30-minutes post-ingestion of supplement, and at the 30-minute time point of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked to rate their feelings of fatigue using a 5-point Likert scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30-minutes post-ingestion of supplement, and at the 30-minute time point of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked to rate their feelings of energy using a 5-point Likert scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30-minutes post-ingestion of supplement, and at the 30-minute time point of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked to rate their feelings of focus using a 5-point Likert scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, 30-minutes post-ingestion of supplement, and at the 30-minute time point of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Subjects were asked to rate their feelings of focus using a 5-point Likert scale

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured continuously during 60 minutes of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Fat oxidation was estimated thru measurements of gas exchange

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measured continuously during 60 minutes of exercise for all three supplement conditions
secondary_outcome.description: Carbohydrate oxidation was estimated thru measurements of gas exchange

arm_group.description: This condition consisted of the ingestion of one serving of the pre-workout supplement.
This condition consisted of the ingestion of 6 mg of caffeine per kg of body mass.
This condition consisted of the ingestion of a placebo.

intervention.description: ENGN Shred is a multi-ingredient pre-workout supplement.
Non-caloric Crystal Light matched for the pre-workout in terms of flavor and consistency.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male
Exclusion Criteria:
- history of medical or surgical events, including cardiovascular disease, metabolic, renal, hepatic, or musculoskeletal disorders;
- use of any medications
- use of nutritional supplements
- habitual use of caffeine (≥1 caffeinated beverage per day)
- participation in another clinical trial or investigation of another investigational product within 30 days prior to screening/enrollment.
